element_texts.text:
Hi - hope all has been well with you two in '78 & will be even better in 79. Shirley is retired on disability & is taking Chemotherapy. 
When it isn't "medicine week" we do lots of nice little things. Had planned to go to Denmark this fall but my 89 yr. old mother went
to the hospital instead - heart ailment. Hopefully we can arrange to get to Arizona in February & not hurry back. Have to find a way
for from? + 87 yr old Aunt em to be looked after while we are away. Keep your fingers crossed that we get to go. Any new work 
lately Jack? Am reading the John Jake's books - nothing at all great about them but they have a certain fascination - sort of a "you were
there" feeling re: history items - and he isn't a bad story teller. A friend calls his stuff semi-porno. So long for now,

Always,   Jewel Wolkenhaur + Shirley too -

Dear Gladys + Jack,
printed  May the beauty of Christmas remain with you throughout the New Year

2- (DAMN TYPEWRITERS ANYWAY! THEY ALWAY [sic] CONK OUT AT THE WRONG TIME)
typed
Here is my question, Mr. Anthony...what kind of split of the profits (percentage-wise) would be fair to offer the printer,
I am well aware of the fact that continued in ink he will bargain for a higher cut if he is interested but thinks the money
isn't enough.

I am to help get the printer + do the promotion (for friendship and a cut, the amount of which we haven't discussed).
When you have time, Jack, I sure would appreciate your suggestion and/or other sources of info on the subject. I am

all enthused because there is no such book for Colorado + there are more visitors (especially more campers) here every year.

Regards to Frisky Fisky + to Gladys. I'll try to write a newsier epistle soon. How is Algren doing, by the way?
News - your bookseller for here has opened a 2nd store - understand rent is $450 a month. How can he do it? The new one

is closer which pleases me, but his wife, a real witch, is in charge - this displeases me. wish him luck anyway, at least he's trying.

Regards from the chick who flew the coop + has never been sorry -    Jewel.

Dear Jack,

Thank you so much for lovely Is the Lee and the two quarterlies.  I shall enjoy the book, I know, for when

Papa Conroy says its good, it is, by gum!

This is the kind of book to be enjoyed in peace and quiet and so far I have had none since its arrival. Out of town

company, a sick (very sick) woman in the house, etc., plus rushing around on my real estate - can you see a serene
moment in that schedule?

postcard
printed LAHAINA WATERFRONT AT EVENING
is a picturesque sight. One of Hawaii's most historic towns,
now a popular residential and visitor community, Lahaina, Maui
was once Capital of the Islands. The CARTHAGINIAN is berthed
near the Lighthouse in front of the Pioneer Inn.
stamp 6c   HELP GOODWILL INDUS  HELP THE HANDICAP picture of Franklin D. Roosevelt
postmark HONOLULU 28 MAY 1971
Dear Gladys + Jack,

There is a lot of history to this place & we looked a bit but we really prefer seeing

rural parts of Hawaii. This is our first trip off the mainland + being very different.

Jewel and Shirley, too.

Mr + Mrs Jack Conroy
701 Fisk
Moberly, Missouri 65270
in red at bottom: Wolkenhauer

Hi, Gladys + Jack -    1972

Have thought of you so often - and wonder if you are keeping busy way down yonder. 

Met Helen Lowrie Marshall last week - she was guest speaker at an Executive's Secretaries
meeting to which I had been invited. She surely must be making a bundle from her plain
little inspirational verses - Doubleday publishes + Hallmark has the right to single items. I
haven't tried writing anything for publication in years but in slow periods in real estate I wonder
about the possibilities. Hope you are continuing, Jack. You have too much gift to not share it.

Have a happy day.     Always,    Jewel.

printed
Somehow the days keep slipping by With so much left undone,
The letters that I mean to write Just never are begun -
But now that it's Thanksgiving time, What I most want to do
Is say "hello" and let you know I often think of you

in pencil Wolkenhaus [sic], Jewel  [1980]
Dear Gladys + Jack,
We finally made our dream trip to Scandinavia this summer + think it will be our last such expensive journey. If we think
prices are high in the USA --!/ My Mom passed on a year ago October don't know if I wrote you. Anyway we took her
sister to Arizona for a month + she stood the trip well. In January we plan to go back to Arizona + hope to stay thru May.
Sure beats Colorado winter. Having 2 houses is bad but we aren't in a position to decide on Arizona as #1 at this point in
time. Hope both of you are well and happy - I do think of you even tho I am a worse correspondent than before.

Fondly,  Jewel

Christmas '81  in pencil: Wolkenhauer, Jewel
Dear Jack,
Sorry to hear that Gladys has been so poorly. Perhaps there has been improvement since you wrote in August.
I hope so./Thanks for sending Will Wharton's review of The Jack Conroy Reader - I loved it.| Of course I never hear
anything about Std. Ed. - never did except from you - but mention if it recalls many memories. some are great - like
recall of our little chats - And some are bad, like my rage at Fisk trying to talk down to you! He always lashed at his
superiors in intellect, the rat./ Things going pretty well here - I had some health problems all summer but am back to just
the usual aches + pains of arthritis. Shirley is doing very well. She'll see her 3 doctors next week for her 6 mo. check-up +
then close to Jan 1 we'll take off for Arizona where we'll stay til about the end of May.    (over)

upside down - card with blue jays and cardinal
We still have my 90 yr. old Aunt to worry about. since she refuses to go to Arizona, we have set up
much support service + hope for the best. she still lives in the apartment she shared with Krom?

Jack, old buddy, I fervently hope that you are withstanding the storms of life and that you manage

somehow to find time to read and, more importantly, to write.   I'll be pleased to hear from you at any
time you have opportunity to write, after Jan. 1 I'll be at : 1224 N. Abrezo Drive, Green Valley, 
Arizona 85614.  If you mislay this, first class mail is always forwarded from Denver.

in pencil Walkenhauser [sic]
2/23/82
Dear Jack,

Thought you'd like to see the enclosed clip - from Arizona Daily Star 2/20/82.

It's a reprint of Mike Royko story on Nelson Algren from the Chicago Sun Times.

All is well here in Green Valley - sure beats the snow + cold of Denver winter.

Shirley is doing fine and our health problems are minor and the very ordinary kind.

Hope Gladys is better and you are perking along.
Any new books in the cooker, Jack? Hope so. I know how much energy you have to

use on you - writing things and just hope you have enough left over.

Think of you often -   Warm regards,    Jewel

in pencil Wokenhaus [sic], Jewel
1224 N. Abrego Drive, Green Valley, Ariz 85614

May 28, 1987

Dear Gladys & Jack,

I brought you last few Christmas notes along when we came to Ariz. in January & mislaid all such til

now when we have to pack up for Colorado within a few days. sorry Gladys has been poorly - hope
things have gotten much better since I last heard.

 And how nice to hear that The Jack Conroy Reader is out. Haven't seen it yet - the bookstore here is

misnamed and others in Tucson surely don't carry much but red hot novels and books on birding or
mining. Hope the book does a steady business, Jack.

 We hate to go back to Denver because life has been so easy here for the past 5 months. But we have

to return.

2-
for Shirley's medical check-ups and to do things for Aunt Emmie - was 90 in April & still 
on her own in the apartment she shared with my mom almost until her death in Oct.'79.

 Perhaps Denver would seem more enticing, despite always more work & problems there, if

air pollution hadn't gotten so bad. Also, it's just another underline overgrown /underline
small city now. Too many people, too much traffic, noise, etc. etc. Hard to believe that * people
with lung trouble used to go to Denver for the pure air.

 All this griping but we'll probably settle in again just fine. Hopefully even get away to our beautiful

Rockies a number of times.

 Do think of you often and hope life is being good to you.  For now,
Warm regards, Jewel.

in pencil Wolkenhauer, Jewel
12/87
Dear Jack, it was so good to hear from you last Christmas. I hope your health has improved - you've had enuf [sic] troubles.
We have had an abundance of health problems too, the past year. Shirley has been battling recurring cancer for 9 yrs. but
she is peppier right now than she has been in years. My troubles are most arthritis - especially knee & ankle but I am improving.
// The author of "Ruffles & Drums" you mentioned retired from the Denver Public School system and moved to the mountains
west of Denver. Then she began teaching for the Jefferson County system. Doesn't write anymore as far as I know but is a good
jokester and a good friend. Missed her this summer while in Denver & she was away when we could have seen her. You'd like
her, Jack. Like you, she is a good story-teller. // I will have to try to locate "The Weed King & Other Stories." Think the local
bookstore can get it for me. I hope sales of it have brought you more than literary acclaim. // Thanks for the dope on Standard Ed.
people - the only names I recognized were Ward & Ewing.  Better sign off for now, dear friend. I do think of you - and fondly.
You were an anchor in Frisky Fisk's nutty world.     Always, Jewel (Wolkenhauer)

1224 N. Abrego Drive

Green Valley, AZ 85614
printed in red with warmest Wishes for the Holidays

in pencil Wolkenhaus [sic], Jewel
Dear Jack

Since I haven't heard from you in a couple of years, I hope all

is well with you and you are just busy.

 I had a nice bookstore man order a couple of your older books

some months ago & have enjoyed having them.

 Nothing much new here in Green Valley - we escaped the summer

heat by going to the northern Arizona mountains and loved it. It's the
closest thing to Colorado in trees, mountains & streams but a lot closer.
Be well and happy, old friend.             Love, Jewel
Ans 1-5-89
printed  Wishing You the Joys of the Season

GOOD CHEER    GOOD HEALTH   GOOD FRIENDS

in pencil Wolkenhauer, Jewel H
Green Valley, AZ
Dec. 11, 1989
FROM THE DESK OF...  Jewel
12/11/89
Dear Carolee,

Thanks for your Nov. 27 letter. Glad Jack is still doing OK & especially glad that he

has you to visit, read to him, bring goodies, etc!

I'll be keeping in touch  Meanwhile, my best wishes for a beautiful Christmas for you

& your family. May 1990 be good to all of you and to Jack.

 Fondly, Jewel

I probably will have knee replacement surgery early in the year so if there are gaps
between letters, know that I haven't stopped thinking of my friends in Moberly.

in pencil Wolkenhauer, Jewel H
Green Valley, AZ
Dec 11, 1989

Dear Jack,

I think of you so often and with such fond memories. I hope you are doing better & better.
It is so nice to live in southern Arizona especially when I recall our Chicago days & blustering
winds & snow. wonder if Cal Fisk is still around somewhere - I never was a good judge of age
but I thought he was older than you or I.

 With every good wish for a better year ahead for you, old friend! I'll be in touch through Carolee.

printed  and a Happy New Year!      Love, Jewel

2/15/90
Dear Carolee,

Thanks for your nice note - they tell me I am doing well. A physical therapist comes 3x weekly

to put me thru the paces - I do the exercises myself in between.

 Am still in pajamas because none of my slacks are wide-legged enough to let me roll up the leg

& pull up the full length elastic stockings and all my skirts are too short & straight. When I
"graduate" to regular clothes it will be a great day!

 So glad Jack hasn't gotten the flu & that he is in   (over)

good spirits.

 I don't wonder that Jack seemed to recognize the name Cal Fisk. That man was the boss

but he was a thorn in our side. He took particular delight in trying to put down anyone who
knew more than he did - and he was especially nasty to Jack - who, with his good humor,
just let it slide. It was us against Cal in the whole department - but we survived.

 Take care of yourself - love to both you & Jack.     Always, Jewel

P.S. Wish you could have heard Jack tell of his adventures with Nelson Algren when they were
young - hilarious.

2/15/90
Dear Jack,

The deed is done - I have a new right knee.  surgery was a month ago today. I would like to

fast-forward the calendar by a month or two for by then the painful exercises would be done.

 Meanwhile, it is vital that I bend and straighten the leg repeatedly so it won't stay bent -

amazing how fast things heal.

 Beginning to get cabin fever - soon I'll be out & about on my walker.

in pencil Wolkenhaus [sic], Jewel
2-  They sure get you moving in a hurry these days.
The sun is shining brightly but we are having a cold snap - it wont get above
the 40's today - and I even saw a few fleeting snowflakes last night. The weather
men are so funny - they go on and on about a cold spell and all it means is a few
degrees drop in temperature.

 Arizona has had a state lottery for a couple of years and this week it had built

to $2 million. Needless to say, I didn't even come close.

3 -  Sure would be nice to win some money but I don't think it will happen.

 This gorgeous little bird, my favorite, came in-person to my back yard this week. He

usually is seen a bit farther south. Wish I could send him to visit you - he is such a joy
to behold. Take  good care - I'll write again soon.    Love, Jewel
printed  VERMILION FLYCATCHER  by Bonnie Swarbrick Morehouse

This spectacular flycatcher is locally common in riparian vegetation near open

water in the arid Southwest. As its bright colors suggest, it is a tropical bird which
ranges south to Argentina. Its latin name Pyrocephalus rubinus, means "ruby-red fire head,"
a fitting description of the male, but unlike most flycatchers, the female is much different,
being brown and white with a tinge of pink on the sides.

 The Tucson Audubon Society
  34 N. Tucson Blvd.
  Tucson, Arizona 85716
  Telephone 323-9673

in pencil Cary
Nov. 5
Dear Jack and Gladys

 Greetings!
 We don't seem to get to Moberly very often, or you two to Kalamazoo!

HOWEVER - John will be reading his poetry next Monday, Nov. 9, at Stevens
(or Stephen's?) College. I guess this is in Columbia, Mo. How far from you?

 He will be flying there, so no car. A Mrs. Elaine Hemley knows the places

and times, if you care to inquire at the English Dept. I think J. will read
underline his /underline poetry in the afternoon, and other people;s
poems at night. Or vice versa! or underline something! /underline

  Peace -  Love, Cary

in pencil Cary [1950's]   Note: probably late 50's

Dear Jack and Gladys,
 Hail to the Senior Associate Editor and wife!
 We were glad to get your note, and learn your new address in time to save this from going astray.
Dave Wagoner was actually in Kalamazoo a couple of weeks ago - first I'd seen him in over 3 years.

He gave a fine Poetry Reading at W.M.U. (Western Michigan University, where John teaches.) Then he was
to read at Penn. State, and at YMHA in NYC. He'll teach again in Seattle in Jan. He took the current
quarter-off.

  John's 2nd bk. will underline probably /underline be published by I.U. Press, maybe in 1961. He had

poems in underline Poetry /underline last summer, and in Vol. 1, No. 1 of underline Poetry Northwest /underline 
edited by Dave's girl friend and talented poet, Carolyn Kr?er.      John studied at Iowa, again last summer. He'll have
poems in a

book to be published this spring with work by writers who have been at S.U.I., edited by Engle, I think.

 Our Dave is seven now, loves first grade and is a fine reader. Dickie is a charming 3-year-old.
 How are Margaret, Jim and the kids?  Hello to them.    This pen is giving me a bad time!
  We'll be in Kalamazoo for Christmas.    All the best,   Cary

what's Algren doing these days?
David Wagoner
1409 - 42nd North
Seattle 2, Wash.
from Kalamazoo, home of the "mill."!

card image of large building
HOTEL GOVERNOR CLINTON
Opposite Pennsylvania Station
New York City

postcard
in pencil  Woods, Cary
New York's Newest and Finest
HOTEL GOVERNOR CLINTON
Seventh Avenue at 31st Street
OPPOSITE PENNSYLVANIA STATION
1200 Rooms
All Outside with Private Bath, Radio, Television, Servidor and
Circulating Ice Water
stamp 2 c
postmark NEW YORK, N.Y. APR 29 1955 AM

Dear kids,
 John & I & some cadets are here on a Spring Tour. Baby is

with my Mom. We're having a grand visit.  Will leave to Chi.
tomorrow. Saw West Point today.   Love,  Cary  in pencil: Woods
Mr. & Mrs. Jack Conroy
6012 S. Green
Chicago, Illinois

POST CARD
stamp 2 c
postmark KALAMAZOO MICH. JAN 23 1956 9 30 PM
Hi - Got your nice letter. Now waiting for the book to come. -

It just came.

After Feb. 1 our new address will be

1716 Southern Ave.
Kalamazoo, Mich.
 your mortgaged friends,    Cary & John Woods

Mr. & Mrs. Jack Conroy
6012 S. Green
Chicago 21, Illinois

in pencil Cary Note: Woods

Christmas, 1961

Dear Jack and Gladys,

 A Joyous Christmas to you, and we hope you enjoy singing this song by John and my brother.
 Jack, will you please give the other copy to Win Stracke? I'd be proud iffen [sic] he'd like to sing it

sometime, as a solo. We have a marvelous record of him singing folk songs - enjoy it so much.
sometimes, on Capt. Kangaroo's show, we hear Win's voice on a record singing "Here comes Mr.
Mailman," also one about building a house. I can't find these - please ask Win what company recorded
these, whether they're in an album, or what! Thanks. blue and red asterisks

 Our biggest news is that Dave Wagoner got married last summer - to a Patricia, and now they are

living at P.O. Box 85, Woodenville, Wash. Dave is on a sabbatical this year. He reports that Patt is
a marvelous dancer and painter. Aside from that we know nothing about her. Dave is still busy writing.

 Tieing [sic] for 1st place in the "biggest news" department is this: John's 2nd

book has been published by Indiana University Press. It is called "On the Morning of Color"
(from a line of a poem dedicated to Dave Wagoner -). 
The book is                      "           to      "         "     and lucky me.

 Please tell the world about the book. Also, I would like to know whether the Chi. underline

Sun Times /underline received a copy for review. 2 red asterisks  Please tell me quick
about that - so if they haven't - I'll see that the Press sends one off. What is the name of the book sect.
editor?  (Publication date was Dec. 11)

 How's your daughter and her family?
 Our boys are as full of fun as always. Dave, 9, is a 3rd grader, and likes to ride his bike to school.

Dick, 5, is happy in Kindergarten.

 J. will give a reading at a small Wisc. college, Lakeland, I think it is, in April. Also, here at WMU on

Jan -9- last March he read at the Jewish Center in Detroit. Does WMFT have any poetry read these
days? Any influence there, Jack?!

 Stay well, and have a new year of peace.    Sincerely,  Cary

Envelope enclosed for replies to red asterisks and red & blue asterisks

postcard
TOWERING DUNES
along the shores of beautiful Lake Michigan, a vacationer's paradise with
hiking, picknicking, fishing, swimming, & camping. a happy combination for a
vacation for the whole family.
stamp 4 c
postmark NE.. MICH. 1963

Aug 7  Sawyer

Dear friends,

 The boys and I are visiting my folks for a bit, while John writes this month

at Yaddo, near Saratoga Springs, N.Y.

 The country-side is lovely, and the lake's perfect.

All the best,  Cary (Woods)
Mr. & Mrs. Jack Conroy
14626 Millard Ave.
Midlothian, Illinois

Mrs. John W. Woods  1716 Southern  Kalamazoo,  Michigan

Dec., 1964

Dear Jack and Gladys,

 How was your trip?
 John spent another good August at Yaddo. W.M.U. issued an L.P. record of John reading poetry from his first

book. did I tell you before? I'll enclose the blurb sheet - please tell all your favorite colleges, libraries, and FM
stations! WMU will bring out a few more poetry records - Don Hall for one, and - it is to be hoped - Dave Wagoner.

 Dave's 4th novel will be out in April or May. A chunk of it will appear in Harper's next spring.
 Our boys are well, and busy with school and friends. Dave, just 12, is in 6th grade. dick, 8, is in 3rd grade. Both

excellent students, and lots of fun.   over

How are Margaret and her children?
  Mom and Dad will join us for Christmas. My brother, Kent, and his wife and little girl

(1 yr. last July) moved to Phoenix, Ariz. from Chi. They like the nice climate. Kent will
look for a teaching job - music. Meanwhile, he's busy with his composing. He has had
quite a few choral compositions published - church anthems, etc.

 Send news!    Love, Cary

in pencil Cary

March 17, 1973

Dear Gladys and Jack,

 We are [[underline years /underline behind in answering your letters.
 Thanks for the "American Book Collector" and your good review of John's book.

Would you be able to get, autograph, and mail to us the 
Autumn '72 and winter '73 issues of NEW LETTERS? That would be great. Hope there are some copies left!!
(Stamps enclosed - let me know if I owe you more.)  Many thanks, if you can do this.

 a Mich. State student has been interviewing John, reading much of his work, etc. She plans to submit this to

NEW LETTERS. So here's hoping they wish to print an article about Woods.

 Dave Ehler wrote 2 very nice reviews of John's work - one was in "NEW: American and Canadian" (or vice versa)

Poetry." The other mag. is "Chicago Review" - current, winter issue - 26th anniversary issue. J. also has poems

on side RaRietan or some such name

in C.R.

Who will publish "The Fields of Golden Glow? and when?
 J. will read in Boise, Id. at some university in early April. He has visited quite a few high schools for

Michigan Arts Council & Indiana A.C.  Do the high schools in Missouri have visiting poets, too?

 I'm going on a trip next week to Wilmington, Del. & Philadelphia, to visit art museums and historic homes.

Really looking forward to it!      Love,  Cary

Dec. - '74
Dear Gladys and Jack,

 I'm later than ever with greetings - sorry!
 It was good to hear about your new book, underline Writers in Revolt /underline last year.
  Wonder of wonders, we got to see Dave Wagoner in '74 !! He gave a poetry reading in May, at

Indiana Univ. - South Bend campus. (during their Writers Conference) John & I drove down to
So. B. and stayed with our friend there, Elaine Hemley. The next day, we brought Dave to Kalamazoo,
for an afternoon reading at W.M.U. (Western Mich. Univ.) and an evening reading at Kalamazoo College.
All 3 programs were great!! Such a fine writer!  His latest poetry bk. is now out from Ind. U. Press -
underline Sleeping in The Woods./underline  double underline Another /underline novel will be
out, next spring or summer. Incredible! We've been very concerned about Patt W., who is recovering from surgery
for breast cancer. Surgery was in Oct., and the outlook is good, Dave reports. But
on side My folks celebrated their Golden anniv. in Sept. They live in Sawyer, Mich. - 60 miles from us.

2.   such trauma!

 John is on a sabbatical this school year - more time to write. He will be Poet in Residence at Purdue Univ.

(Lafayette, Ind.) Jan 13 until the end of April. Will be there Tues.-Thurs., then drive up to Kal. Fri. to Monday.

 Dave, 22, is troubled with schizophrenia, and has been in & out of Kal. State Hosp. for treatment for the past

2 years.  Had to go back in, in May. He comes home weekends and holidays to visit us. We see him almost
daily at the hosp. Dave is better now, and recently began a work program.

 Rich, 18, is our key musician. He is a very good guitar player (elec.) and is in a little band. They practice 

regularly, and have had a underline few {/underline]] jobs.

 I've learned a bit this year about patchwork and quilting, enjoyed numerous concerts, poetry readings, and

movies - Wendell Berry and Thomas Kinsella were here lately - both good. 

 Our friend, poet Dave (David Jeddie) Smith now teaches at Cottey College, Nevada, Missouri. John underline

may /underline give a reading there, Jan. 10. Cottey is a 2-year private school for women, I gather.
on side Dave's [Smith] 3rd bk. of poems is out - from Ohio U. Press.  Send news.    Love, Cary

in pencil  Wright, Clifford [no date]
stamp Danmark 35
Dear Jack:

Don't give us up. WE now Expect to leave for the U.S.A. in February.
Our holidays were fun & 2 American's plus lots of Danes graced our halls.
Best,  Clifford

Jack Conroy
crossed out: 6012 S. Green St., Chicago, Illinois, U.S.A.
14626 S Millard ave
Midlothian ILL

postcard
Wright c/o Maas
62? Montacue St.
Brooklyn, N.Y.
postmark NEW YORK Feb 22 1951 9 30 PM
stamp 1c
Jack:  Thank you for the Christmas card. All goes well this winter & I not only
eat regularly but am warmly & luxuriously housed. Did you see that Mitrapoulous is
going to do Ben's piece?     Best, Clifford
Mr. Jack Conroy
6012 S. Green St.
Chicago, Illinois

postcard
[[in pencil: Wright, Clifford
stamp Danmark 35
postmark KOBENHAVN 9 NOV 1956
Dear Jack: Look where I am! Copenhagen is a marvelous city & I hope to stay here a year.
I came on a shoestring but I have been promised a show here & one in Brussels  if I can hold
out a couple of months all will be well. How are you & what are you up to? The Danes have
a very jolly drink called Aqua Vit which I can assure you is very invigorating.

 Best, Clifford wright

c/o Gress, 13 Telglaardstrade
Copenhagen, Denmark
Mr. Jack Conroy
6012 South Green St.
Chicago, Illinois
U.S.A.

HAPPY 1961 from the Gress-Wrights
Aase[?] Skole
par Glans0
(Come visit us!  Best, Clifford)
Jack Conroy

14626 S Millard
Midlothian ILL

35, Arggll[?] Mansions,
London. W. 14.

 Overseas Anthology (III Series)

The above book to which you contributed is now published at $1.50, but you are entitled to as many copies as you may require at 80c.

I cannot trace having received any order from you and shall be glad to know your requirements, as soon as possible, as the edition is

limited, and cannot be reprinted.

Yours faithfully,

p.p.  S. Fowler Wright    WG.

Stephen Wright
Box 1341
F.D.R. Post Office Station
New York, N.Y. 10022

June

Dear Jack,

 I forgot to include this review of underline Different * /underline with my letter -

from the underline Chicago Tribune /underline.

 Steve

I am sending you a copy of the book too.

in pencil: Wyman, Dave [no date]
June 17
Dear Jack:

Thanks for "What Every Young Boy Should Know". It's a wow! I know I should have written you long before this, but I can only

plead ignorance. School ended Friday, and now I have a little more time than before.

My novel Rock will be out on August 18th. Let me know whether you'll be getting a review copy from the Sun Times. If not, I'll send you one.

My book of poems, A Place to Stand, will be out sometime in July. I don't have copies of either yet.

I was offered a job in Dangerous Dick's Dept. at Berkeley, but they upped my salary here, gave me some better courses, and the balance-pan fell

in Seattle. I saw Tony Ostroff in San Francisco when I was giving a poetry reading, but we didn't have much time to talk.

I'm writing a play (Echo: "Who isn't?") and I hope to have a first draft finished by mid-July Anyway, whenever I wind it up, I'm heading for the

Midwest to spend a week or two with my parents in whiting. I hope you and Gladys will be around then, and not off to Missouri or Oregon.

Nothing much to report on the gossip front. I feel out of touch. I don't know where anybody is or what anybody's doing. you tell me. It was good
to see the letter from Clifford Wright. His changeover and marriage are two of the wonders of our time. He was known as the Queen of Seattle when

he lived here, I'm told. I understand John Woods has another book of poems ready. Hope he peddles it without trouble. He seems to me a marvelously
talented guy, and that's sometimes a handicap.

Even after my long delinquency, this letter ought to earn me a note from you. Tell me of the time and times. Sing the random light made whole.
  Best,   Dave W.

April 28, '55
Dear Jack:

Sorry to hear you haven't been well, take care of those fancy innards of yours, and don't let them start a revolution. Remember there are clean

bones crying in the flesh - don't betray them yet.

The Algren letter was delightful: I showed it to a number of people here, and it had to go into several extra printings. Most thought it ranked

favorably with Thurber's reply to Sam Goldwyn. let me know how all the litigation comes out. Man is wolf to the man.

Here things go their hectic course. My second novel has been sent to the printer, and I'll be getting the proofs before long. I'll have a copy sent

to you this summer, as soon as it comes out. It is, I hope fervently, a great deal better than the first. I've been writing some poems, not many, but
enough to assure myself I haven't disappeared. Karl Shapiro showed up today (he's giving a reading tonight), and he looks brown and chipper from
his stay in Berkeley. He's met El Hagapian and likes him.

Did you hear about the Oppenheimer fiasco at our U? Higher education crawls forward. However, the strike raised about the refusal to permit him

to lecture has had some healthy effects: they (the president and the regents) won't be as quick to act high-minded next time. The faculty really has
given them a roasting about it.

I hope to get to work on a new book before many days pass. I can feel it starting a log-jam in the back of my mind.
Tell me some news from your land - Algren, Woods, Gladys, anybody else. I miss all of you.
    All things,    Dave W.

in pencil Wyman, Dave
61 Columbia Dr.
Amherst, Mass. 01502
May 13, 1977
Dear Jack,

I am awfully rushed with final exams & grades, getting the garden planted, & setting up our trip to the Midwest. so, I write for

two quick purposes only.

First, I want to pick up one sentence in your letter of March 7 when you mentioned that if I ever get out your way I could drop in

to see you. My wife, Midge (I call her Midgie, or chicken) & I annually pilgrimage as far into the wilds as Indianapolis to visit her
parents & relatives. and it happens that this particular year we are intent on taking an extra week to go on to Iowa & Missouri to see
old friends & old nostalgic places. We met at a little Quaker college (Wm. Penn Col.) in Oskaloosa, Iowa, a town not too far north of you
on a route you in Moberly must know well, US 63. I also spent some ^nine of my prime ^youthful months in Springfield, MO, in the
federal pen with 20 other conscientious objectors in 1949 for refusal to have anything to do with Cold War conscription. Anyway, we
will be in your environs

2
sometime during the week or so from May 29 through June 5. If you will be home & will have some time free, we would love to see you.
We'll be travelling [sic] by car, so no problem getting there. If possible, we'd like very much to see the Monkey Nest area & ^other such places
from The Disinherited. If a visit seems workable from your standpoint, could you send us a note giving the best day - crossed out your
preference of dates. If you could give more than one date, it would probably make our trip scheduling easier, but that is not essential. By now
it's too late for a letter to get to Amherst before we set out on the first leg of our trip. So write to me c/o H. Austin Smith 309 S. Ritter Ave.
Indianapolis, Indiana 46219   If we have from you there, we'll phone from Indpls. on May 25th or so to make final arrangements. Would you
send your phone number & brief directions to your house?

I bought a copy of Writers in Revolt, but haven't had a chance to read it yet. Midgie broke it in & reports that it is hard to put down.
My second purpose is to report on the response of

3
my spring semester ^ (just freshly finished) freshman - sophomore U.S. History survey course group to The Disinherited.
29 of the 33 enrolled were in class to fill out the book evaluations. To the crucial question ("Should this book be used next year?"),
27 said yes, 1 said no, & 1 was neutral. Some of the comments were pretty interesting; I'll bring them along. They were pretty
excited when I mentioned that I might see you this summer.

Congratulations on the doctor of Humane letters. It is an apt degree for you. Your writing is most human anyway, & humane,

also, in the best sense.    Hope to be seeing you.

 Best,   Dave Wyman

Shaker Rd. } Summer only
Canterbury, N.H. 03224
July 6, 1977
Dear Jack:

 Indeed, your nice letter of May 18 underline was /underline lying in wait for us in the Amherst

post office when we reached home. It must have come the day after we set out on our journey. Midge
(Chicken) & I are very, very glad we made connections anyway. We wouldn't have missed that afternoon
with you for anything. It was a peak, in a week that was crowded with high points for us. You are every
bit as fascinating, deep-reading, & yet light-hearted as your books & your letters.

 We hope your wife is up & around & feeling well again.  We elected to stay at that Swiss Village Motel

you pointed out & found it is still inexpensive ($13 for us two) & clean &, best of all, quiet. All our memories
of the "Athens of the West" are good ones. The next morning, the Sunday we headed north to Ottumwa &
Oskaloosa, Iowa, was a HOT one. It hit 101 [degrees] in Des Moines that day, we heard. We contended
with a mild 96 [degrees] in eastern Iowa. Nonetheless, we sought out the meadow & woods we used to to
"courtin' " in, in the days at Penn College when we were first going together. But first we had to work  our
way through a new housing development & high school & that sort of litter that has junked up one end of
the old college farm.

 I'm enclosing your review of Richard Wright. I enjoyed it a lot & made a xerox of it. Also, instead of sending

you a copy of underline Writers in Revolt /underline to replace the autographed copy you gave us, I'm
enclosing $4. Actually, I wanted the second copy -- so I'd rather send the money than the book. The price on
the book is $3.95, but I feel foolish making out a check for that. If $4 doesn't cover your cost, be sure to let me
know & I'll send the difference.     (over)

I got a laugh out of your Feiffer cartoon. I'll put it on my office door this fall, for my colleagues' edification. with

a great stroke of luck I have managed to set up a year off (starting in January) to write ^ (at last) my sequel to
underline Paper Walls. /underline  I've been researching this second book since 1969 & have about 14 cartons
of materials, but I've had no long stretch of time to start writing. when I reached home I learned that Pantheon Books
(part of Random House) was trying to reach me. They wanted me to send some of my stuff. Luckily, besides underline
Paper Walls /underline, I had a 9-page outline of the current work & drafts of 3 speeches I've made based on the newer
research. On the strength of that, they offered (& I accepted) a contract with a $12,000 advance & $2,000 more for paperback
rights for underlinePaper Walls /underline. By coughing up $4,000 ^ of our own (half our life's savings!), we can
afford to take leave from the groves of our academy for a full year & get the damned job done at last. It still looks too good
to be true, but I have it in black & white -- ^ in a legal contract! This beats playing with the damned foundations. Imagine
Guggenheim putting you off with some imbecility about using the money for promising beginners! As if they couldn't find
the funds for both. I'll be working with Andre Schiffrin, whom Studs Terkel acknowledges very impressively in underline
Hard Times /underline & underline Working /underline. (I haven't seen the newest Terkel, but enjoyed your review in
underline Foolkiller.) /underline

 The NH countryside is beautiful & comparatively peaceful. We have the garden almost our from under the weeds. It's growing

luxuriantly so far, though we are beginning to need more rain. Woodchucks did a job on the beans while we were away, but
^ that's come to a stop.

 Again, we both thank you for a delightful afternoon. The Monkey Nest trip was ^a very moving experience. And we treasure

those wonderful autographs.    Best, Dave (the Sage of Canterbury, pro tem) & Chicken

in pencil [1977]

 We're late getting our cards sent out, but we hope you had a  happy Christmas. We did. Went to our little "farm" in

New Hampshire, both the kids were there and we enjoyed roaring fires in the fireplace, games of parcheesi & cards, 
hauling up wood & sawing it so we could have those roaring fires etc.

 We hope Gladys is feeling fine again and that both of you will have a healthy, happy year ahead.       Love,

printed  Wishing You a Very Merry Christmas and a Wonderful New Year

    Midge drawing of a chicken & David

in pencil  Wyman, Dave
61 Columbia Dr.
Amherst, Mass. 01002
1/3/78
Dear Jack,

 Last night the ground hereabouts was bare of snow, which I like, but which does seem unnatural for this section at

this time of year. But today the first real snowstorm of the new year has already changed the picture. About 3 inches
of a predicted 6 to 8 has drifted down. Looking out back from my desk window I'm treated to a colorful gathering 
around Midge's bird feeders. Even a cardinal, which is a ^rather rare & special treat for New Englanders. They stand
out sharply against the snow.

 We enjoyed your letter of Nov. 16 & had a long laugh from your music writing ("I'm a Yankee Doodle Dandy") as an

explanation for the quintet of flags on your address sticker.

 Congratulations on the Natl Endowment for the Arts award! I hope this means that your autobiography will make a

quantum leap & be completed. Also felicitations on being * on side "author of the year" for Missouri. I would have
so voted.    Glad you liked the bookplates. Here are 2 other photos Midge took in June, to add to your collection.

 The poster with you at the Moberly depot is precious. I used it in class &, then hung it on my office bulletin board

where it is yet.

 underline The Disinherited /underline was well received again this fall in my class on the 20's & 30's. Of the 27

in class the day I had the books rated, 24 thought it should be read again next year (which I see as the acid test of a book),
2 thought not, & one offered no response. That is an excellent record, but not unusual for your book. That class, by the way,
while smart enough to recognize the value of underline The Disinherited /underline (& generally quite able mentally),
was the quietest, least responsive group I've had in 6 or 7 years. Nothing I did seem to stir them. I hope we are not

Midge & Dave Wyman   June 1977

On US 40 (The National Road) in Indiana

To The Sage of Moberly

from the Sage & Sagess of Amherst
  Dave           Chicken
8/11/78

in pencil  Wyman, Dave [1978]
MICHIGAN STATE UNIVERSITY
Society For The Study Of Midwestern Literature
Bessey Hall
East Lansing - Michigan 48824

Sept. 15

Dear Jack:

 You're there - on p. 4. What we've done - and I guess it wasn't such a good idea - is

list the MSU members first for clerical convenience.

 We are making some progress, and I think we'll have a functioning center. If you have any

ideas, we'll be happy to have them.    You know, Jack, we don't believe in moral turpitude - only
evil spirits out there. It's good to hear from you.     Best,  Dave

in pencil Wyman, Dave
12/12/80
Dear Sage of Moberly:

Ahoy & avast, me hearty!   It has been another summer & part of a winter too since I've written. But it's not that we 

don't often think of you.    I hadn't taught my 1920-40 course since the fall of 1977, until I got back into it the past spring.
(the g ap came because of my time off & halftime stints in 1978-79.) I've repeated it again this fall. small classes each time,
because "out of sight, out of vogue" in the groves of academe. anyhow, the newcomers, as had the old, appreciated
underline THE DISINHERITED /underline. On my anonymous book-rating form, 30 of 31 acclaimed the book & agreed
that it should be used next time the course is given. Fortunately for the benighted dissenter, the survey was anonymous.

 The N.H. summer outdid itself for mosquitoes. So bad, it was the talk of the state for 6 weeks. The bird-life was also at a peak,

& that was a pleasure. The wood thrushes began to turn up the summer before. Then this past summer they seem to have staked
out a mile-long strip along our road, several hundred feet back, in the forest's ^edge. Their flute sound is near magic.

 The old place looked like it had been moved to Missouri or Iowa. The Shaker colony borders us on two sides, & the farmer leasing

their fields went in big for corn. underline Tall /underline corn. Way over my head. Midge got a little peeved as the growing
season went on. She declared it was not New England-like & if she wanted to live in the Midwest she would have settled there.
(Bless her transplanted Hoosier corn-fed soul -) Imagine a chicken kickin' about being hemmed in by corn! "It blocks the

view of the hills, "she complained." I have to go up on the roof to see the mountings." She may be 
drumming up a brigade of raccoons or a few thousand gross of giant cut worms for next summer.

 Still my book is not done. Thirteen chapters (of 15) are, though. so the tunnel's end may yet

lighten.    Son Jim married in June, choosing a Minnesota denizen. We flew out for the wedding,
but made no side trips whatever., & flew right back to the grind. They are living in the Minneapolis
area, so we will be making that pilgrimage from time to time.

 Hope you & Gladys are doing fine. Midge had some low-grade virus that kept her at half-pace for

about 6 weeks last summer. And I had a touch of flu in October. But otherwise, fine. My bad disk has not
given any real problems for a long time. ^Last summer I even got away with hefting some 80-pound
fertilizer bags & breaking up a stubborn tree with the chain saw without after effects.

 Well, I'm pulling for spring & summer already. & here it is hardly into full winter.
   Best o' luck,     Dave & Mildred

in pencil Wyman, Dave
Shaker Rd.
Canterbury, NH 03224
7/25/82
Sage of Moberly:
Dear Jack,

 Is the paperback edition of underline The Disinherited /underline out of print?
 Last year I didn't teach the course that I use it in. And when I went to order it for this

fall I couldn't find it in the catalogs.

 I hope there is a way to get it. The students need that book!
 I'm underline still /underline working on my sequel to underline Paper Walls. /underline

First draft is done. The revising is 40% done. Should be close to   (over)

the end of it by the opening of classes. It has been a long haul.

 Midge is having a grand time in her garden. The official soil type is

"Paxton stony loam." But I call it "Paxton loamy stone." Still, it grows
things fabulously well. Mostly it is probably Chicken's touch.

 We have a new greyhound, name of Blazer (named for the Dog Star).

He is a sweet pup (15 months old).

 Hope things are going fine for you.    Very best,     Dave Wyman

Clifford Wright
223 Mott St.
Apt. One

 Our Christmas postcard crosses paths with your letter. We're sorry to hear of Gladys's death; her

last years can't have been easy for either of you. We hope you're feeling OK.

 Thanks for the good news about the new edition of underline The Disinherited /underline;

I feel as if we got our copy of the first edition just under the gun, & can now get the new one with

18 February 1971
Mr. Jack Conroy
701 Fisk Avenue
Moberly, Mo. 65270

My dear Mr. Conroy:

I have been enjoying your literary production over the past few years; therefore, I finally decided to sit down - in
the blissfulness and tranquility of an early Thursday morning - to write you this.  I am a French professor at the  above
named University and am particularly fond of your earliest work, e.g. A WORLD TO WIN and THE DISINHERITED.
I want to thank you and congratulate you most heartily for your impressive literary achievements which have truly
and justly won you many readers from all over.

At this time, I would like to address you several questions sincerely hoping you will take time from your present

schedule to answer them. I really hope you'll indulge this request from a most underline interested, /underline
enthusiastic reader of yours.

 Mr. Conroy, what are your present activities, literary and others?
 Who has influenced you the most in your fructuous literary career?
 May I also ask you... which of your works is your personal favorite (or the one you consider your best)?

in pencil [Yoken]
261 Carroll Street
New Bedford, Mass. 02740
17 August 1981
Hope you enjoy the enclosures!
Dear Jack:

It's been such a long time between letters and I sincerely hope this one finds you in fine fettle and

in top-notch health.   How is that autobiographical oeuvre coming along, Jack? (It should be ready
for publication, n'est-ce pas? Or close to that point, in any event!) Have you undertaken any literacy
projects as of late? I do keep so very busy with all my manifold endeavors - university, civic and social -
thus I never seem to have any free time. No rest for the weary, as they say! Stay well and do stay in
touch -  Most cordially,  Mel

in pencil Yoken, Mel
261 Carroll Street
New Bedford, Mass. 02740
4 Dec. 82
Dear Jack:
Hard to believe that the year is fast waning. Where of where do the months disappear to?
The final countdown will soon begin for 1984, that year which Orwell described as the
symbol of an anti-utopian future.  Enough has happened in our own time and country to
make it disturbingly easy to comprehend and believe in Orwell's society, n'est-ce pas!!
We (Cindy and I) hope that you are well and in good spirits. We are surviving, and
that's what counts. Our three young sons are a handful plus and keep us excruciatingly
busy - as you well can imagine! I do hope that we will all meet one day soon.

 Most cordially, Mel

in pencil  Yoken, Mel B.
261 Carroll Street
New Bedford, Mass. 02740
28 June 83
Has THE DISINHERITED ever come out in a underline new /underline paperback edition - as planned?

Dear Jack:
I did send you a letter around the 1982 (December) holidays, and have wondered whether or not you ever received

it. sometimes the mails are so erratic that it's a small wonder (miracle!) if anyone receives anything at all. (Just
today, I received a letter from NY City postmarked 23 June, and one from Paris postmarked 22 June! C'est la vie,
n'est-ce pas!)... I am directing a French Institute and keeping underline bien sur, /underline extremely busy.
Last summers program was an outstanding success, so I'm hoping for the same outcome in 1983. so far, so good!
It's a herculean task, but I'll survive it all. How are you spending the summer, Jack?
Any new writings?   Best cordial wishes   Mel

in pencil  Yoken, Mel
261 Carroll Street
New Bedford, Mass 02740
12.05.83
Has your autobiography ever been published?
Dear Friend Jack,

I really like the new edition - in paper back - of THE DISINHERITED. and your introduction is excellent.

I bought myself a copy just recently, and have already recommended it to a slew of students and colleagues.
Has the book been a good seller since it came out last year, Jack? How many college classes are using it?
I just wish you lived in these "far eastern" bailiwicks. In this way, I could call on you to give a talk to a good
number of groups over which I preside. They always seem to be looking for a good speaker, and I always seem
to get called on to make the arrangements -  Warmest, best wishes to you, to all - Most cordially,  Mel

261 Carroll Street

3  February 84
ps - Hope you enjoy the enclosures!
Dear Friend Jack -
I am continuing my gospel - preaching the fine parts of THE DISINHERITED! Early
in March, I will give a review of the book before a local library group. It might even become
a classic one day! (It's nearly that now.)  Is Professor Douglas Wixson making any headway
toward the publication of your earlier stories, Jack? He seems like a man who is a kindred
spirit. You got through the hottest summer in 50 years, and now you're going through the
coldest winter in a century. Hard to believe that Missouri recorded such incredibly low
temperatures in December and January! Perhaps the climate is really changing... By the by
have you seen Michel Fabre lately? Is he still at the Sorbonne?   Most cordially,  Mel

in pencil  Yoken, Mel

The Ides of February 86

Dear Jack -
I haven't heard from you in such a long time, and am concerned. Are you OK? Did you get my letter
sent about 4 months ago?... Your silence is disconcerting!

I often wonder whether Professor Douglas Wixson ever finished the collection of your stories? (Is he still

teaching at the University of Missouri, Jack?)

 Cindy and I underline just /underline saw THE COLOR PURPLE, and we are wondering if you saw it?

It was certainly a memorable experience - and an emotionally draining one. The performances were
extraordinary - especially that of Whoopi Goldberg.

Warm, good wishes to you, Jack.    Most cordially, Mel

Dear Friend Jack -

First of all, Cindy, the boys and I would like to wish you the best of holidays, and warm, good wishes for
your continued good health and happiness. It is our fervent hope that you will be blessed with many more
birthdays to come...December 5th is the day for celebrating!

I haven't heard from you in many a moon, and am concerned... do keep in touch, if it is only a word or two!

Doug Wixson and I have exchanged a few letters. Doug & Suzanne seem to be kindred spirits with Cindy and
me. (Tis a small world, n'est-ce pas!)  As a friend and colleague, I am honored to reiterate the good wishes
extended by all members of my family -    Warmest regards,   Mel

in pencil Yoken, Mel
261 Carroll Street

17 Feb. 87

Dear Friend Jack,

Hope you're surviving this wild and wooly winter. The past few days have been clear and seasonable;

however, from mid January to about a week ago, we've been hit very hard by snow and cold - and ice!
we pride ourselves in this 20th century for having so far overcome the forces of nature that we can even
send man to the moon. But, when up to 18 inches of snow is dumped along the coastal region - often
being pummelled [sic] by a similar snowfall a few days before! - our ego is put through a veritable wringer.

The great snowfalls in this region have some interesting results. One is the bringing together of neighbors

who haven't

-2-
met for a confab in months.

Are you watching AMERIKA, Jack? Any reactions pro or con? Criticism has come from

all quarters, but mainly the left. Liberals charge the film is a "blueprint for Star Wars," and
some conservatives think the Soviets may be portrayed as having "compassion." In any
event, most Americans can be trusted to form their own judgment of Soviet communism
by its record over the past 70 years - and not on the basis of a TV miniseries.

When you next see Doug and Suzanne, please send them my best. They do seem like fine

people - and kindred spirits. Did you know Arna Bontemps personally? I've always been
impressed by his writing - as I have with yours.   Keep in touch.  Cordially,  Mel

in pencil Yoken, Mel
December 1988
Dear Friend Jack -
printed Greetings of the season and warmest wishes
for a New Year of happiness.

You know that we wish you the very best, especially good health. We think of you often!
Cordial, friendly regards from your Massachusetts devotees
  Mel, Cindy, Andrew, David Jonathan

Jan. 8, 1973
Dear Jack,

 When I returned from Philadelphia, I got your Christmas card with note. I

am happy to know you are off on your autobiography. It should be interesting
and revealing. The Chicago period is so rich. Do you have a Publisher? I want
to reserve a copy.

 Again, I want to thank you for all your help. If you have not received my book,

let me know.     PEACE 1973  LOVE  Martin

April 4, 1973
Dear Jack,

This will be a note to say that I appreciate deeply your effort on behalf of my book. It continues to have some sale and some good

reviews are coming in - also one negative one (everyone does not like my writing!) But, as Willa Cather said, serious fiction should be
controversial - or I like to think so.

I'm wondering, Jack, whether you would do me a favor. Could you send on to me a copy of your review for the News - even if it is not

to appear. Of course I am hoping very much it will appear. But I'd like to have this copy, for, with your name on it, I think it could be
helpful to quote in trying to sell the book to a paperback house. No sale yet - but we are trying! So if you can send a copy on to me, I'd
appreciate it much!    I took your suggestion and contacted the University of Missouri - I do hope there is still

stock. I'm very eager to read the start of your biography - Should be very, very interesting.

I have a fine letter from Ashley Buck today - thanking you (and me) in receiving copy of

Remember Me to Marcie. He is a sweet, kind person.

Again, I do want to thank you for everything, and I hope things go well with you.
  Gratefully,   Martin

in pencil Yoseloff, Martin
January 14, 1975

Dear Jack,
 I must get this off to you to thank you for your wonderful compliment of including one of my novels in your list of Outstanding

Books of 1955-1975.

A Time to Be Young holds a special place in my heart because I completed it after a long hiatus, during which I wondered whether

I'd ever finish another book.

I saw Ashley and Virginia when they were in New York. We had a memorable lunch at Pete's Tavern, O'Henry's drinking place. Have

you ever been there? If not, I'll sure take you there the next time you are in the city. This brings me to ask whether you might come to
New York. It seems to me in a letter in the recent past you said you might be coming. I do hope so.

Royalties for me have been slim too. I might have told you that Remember Me to Marcie

received a Priority Rating from the American Library Association, and I did make a little money on this one. It is due out in
paperback from Popular Library, but there has been a reorganization there, and the publication has been delayed.

I like going to college campuses, but I know it is very hard today. I did give a talk at Bucknell University.^ in November.

They seem to like what I say and keep calling me back. It's just a small fee, but it helps.

I'm trying to get a new novel written, but with teaching more hours, my time is limited, and it goes slowly. But it goes, for

which I am more than grateful.

I look forward to reading your whole autobiography. It should be something!   May 1975 be a great year for you and Gladys.
Again, my deep appreciation for your including A Time to Be Young. Should you have a copy, or a xerox or anything - the list that 

included it  will you send one on?  Do write.    Best to you and Gladys -     Martin

in pencil   Yoseloff, Martin
New York, NY
Dec 15, 1975
printed  All good wishes for you at this Season and through the year ahead /print

Dear Jack,
 I hope things go well. underline Remember Me to Marcie /underline has just

been published in paperback by Popular Library. They did a tasteful job. I do appreciate, 
as always, your good words and encouragement. May 1976 be a wonderful year for you
and Gladys.     Affectionately,  Martin

in pencil Yoseloff, Martin [1976] [sic: 1978?]
transcribing the bottom part first
printed in red Wishing you all the Joys of the Holiday Season AND A VERY Happy New Year
Dear Jack,

I do hope the writing - and the Life goes well. I often think of you - and I eagerly await your autobiography.

I have just finished revision on my new novel - "What Are Little Girls Made Of?" Out in 1978. May the
New Year be a   (over - up)
Memorable One for you and Gladys.

 With deep affection,     Martin

transcribing the bottom part first
in pencil: Yoseloff, Martin
1979
Dear Jack,

I must get off this note to you to tell you how deeply I appreciate that fine review of What Are Little Girls Made of?

in the Kansas City Star.  It was even more gratifying to know that it was their lead review. You are aware
continued at top, upside down I am writing to her, Ashley and I go back to the 1940's - and WWII. A wonderful guy.

I look forward to seeing you again - do try to make New York! Meanwhile all the best with your books - get that autobiography

done!   Affectionately,  Martin

was elated to see your words - and the wonderful space the novel got.

Do tell Gladys I think about her, and I hope things go better for her.
I'm very saddened about Ashley Buck's condition. A sweet note from Virginia -
 I am sure, that the New York papers (I'm including the Times) give A-1 space to

the big best sellers, no matter how mediocre, now. The Times has reviewed every
novel I've ever written, but not this one.

Be that as it may, I

in pencil [1981]

I do h ope things go well. When will the autobiography be available? I'm waiting.

Of course, I'm working on a new novel.

Affectionately,    Martin

Remember me very warmly to Gladys -   M.
printing in red  Season's Greetings and Best Wishes for a Happy New Year

in pencil Yoseloff, Martin New York, NY Dec 17, 1986
PLEASE LET ME HAVE SOME WORD.    MY [his initials]

To You Both - A Very Happy 1987

I do hope things go well for you. Bob Parrish of Chicago sent me a clipping with
the great news you had won a Lifetime Writing Award.   I await your autobiography.

After three drafts, I have completed my new novel, The Wednesday Game. It will

be published next summer. With deep affection,   Martin
printed: May the Peace and Joy of the Holiday Season be yours Today and Always

in pencil Yoseloff, Martin
139 West 15th Street
New York, N.Y. 10011
January 11, 1987

Dear Jack,
 What a pleasure to hear from you! And I'm happy to know you had your stories published in a new

volume. The review in the Chicago Times is accurate and thoughtful. You richly deserve it!

 Bob Parrish send me a clipping from a Chicago paper announcing you had won a Lifetime Achievement

Award for your works. Again, so richly deserved.

 I was deeply saddened to know of Gladys' death. She was pure gentleness and humanity.
 The news about your losing part of your left leg was truly saddening, too. The fact that you are now somewhat

recovered buoys me. I hope by next writing you'll be underline recovered /underline.

 I would be elated to have you review my new novel, underline The Wednesday Game, /underline anywhere

you can. I want you to know that your reviews of my books have been a strong incentive to keep me writing. I'll
make sure the publisher gets a review copy to you. The novel will be out in September.

 I plan to be in Mason city the week of June 12-19 - my first return in twenty years?   I always wish for the best for

you. Do keep in touch.  Happy New Year!     Affectionately,  Martin

card
printed with Every Good wish for Your Happiness this Holiday Season
Dear Jack,

 I do hope things are going well for you. My new novel, underline The Wednesday Game, /underline

will be out in April. I'll get a copy to you. Let me have some word.

 Affectionately, Martin

in pencil Yoseloff, Martin [1988]
printed  May the serenity of the season last throughout your year

Dear Jack,
 May your holidays be merry! May 1989 bring all Good Things to you.
With deep affection,   Martin
